climbs.name: When I Meet You Around the Corner

content.description:
This ascends a pretty, little arete you can sneak around onto from inside the Jericho alcove. The bottom half protects adequately with medium to large cams (Camalot #2, 3, & 4), and the top half is a fun, easy, but unprotected arete. You can pretend you're on the last pitch of

Yellow Spur

.... ;)

Begin either with deep, vertical cracks right on the bulgy arete (brushy and awkward) or use big cracks and flakes on the right wall (inside the Jericho base area) to move up and "around the corner" onto the arete above the bushes. After that, you'll feel like a sweepstakes winner moving up the runout-but-solid arete above. Building an anchor up top might be difficult.

This could make a nice first pitch to

Mike's Dihedral

, which lies just above.
content.protection: A few medium cams or solo.
content.location:
On the left edge of the base area of Jericho, leave the ground a few steps left of

The Horns of Jericho

, the obvious bolted line in the middle of the smooth wall.

content.description:
This is a tiny pitch of fairly nice granite up and left of the main face of Jericho. It certainly catches your eye as you climb on the Triangles or look up and left from lower Jericho. It looks a bit loose from a distance, but a mild cleaning gave up a bit of nice climbing. Mike Endicott suggested the line but was unable to be there for our first go.

On FA, we rapped in to avoid harming the rope with rock cleaning. We approached fairly similarly as for the main part of Jericho but aimed for a flattish, cap-like boulder above this corner. You can also traverse carefully from the top of Jericho on a grassy but exposed ledge.

We belayed off to the side with a #4 Camlot (old size) to the left, but small cams can work. Pulling up into the dihedral tempts one to step on the jutting flake on the right, but that'll go, so you can use a foothold just below to be safe. A short climber may find the start reachy. Continue up the dihedral and look left for pro. At times, the right wall will lure you. Near the top, the crux seems to involve trusting or not trusting a feldspar-rich hold (I didn't).

Beware of the cactus up and right on the topout ledge.
content.protection: The dihedral protects with mostly small cams, blue Alien to #0.75 Camalot and a #3 Camalot. A #4 Camalot to belay at the start is nice. The belay at the top can be a #0.5, #2, yellow and red Aliens with long slings.
content.location:
This is up and left of the Jericho buttress. The start is left of the top of

The Horns of Jericho

.

climbs.name: Justin Time
climbs.fa: likely climbed previously as a TR variation of adjacent routes

content.description: Climb the shallow arete between the north face and west face of Jericho using an almost continuous crack system. Pull over the initial overhang, and go straight up. There is good pro all the way.  {Note: the route passes just right of a large detached block on the left side of the arete that could move given enough force.}
content.protection: A standard rack to a #2 cam, mostly mid-range cams and stoppers. You can use top anchors from routes on either side.
content.location:
This is just right of the conical pine and 10 feet left of

Fit the Battle

. This could be considered a variation to the

Fit...

anchors, but it can be climbed independently from either of the two cracks to the right that apparently are already variations of

Fit...

.

content.description: This is the short slab to the east of the conical juniper. It has no clear crux, but it does have consistent movement and a picturesque location.
content.location: This is on the north-facing slab, just to the left of the conical juniper.

content.description: This is the trad line that generally sticks to the easternmost (climbers left) of the two shallow cracks that split the west face of Jericho.
content.location: It is on the west face of Jericho, facing into the large cirque (looking across at the Upper Tier).
